body:
Yeah, I wasn't all that happy with this fix, I just wanted to give the option of a quick merge if we wanted to get 1.9.0 out. 

Other options I could see to do this:

- pass a `--log` CLI option along with `--raw`. It might be a little bit messy to get the name cleanly out to build the command, and also a bit messy inside the `run()` to put the filename back in.
- Trigger some logic along with with `args.raw` (effectively just moving where this decision to use try_numer or try_number+1 lives.)
- Don't increment try_number in the TI row on the DB until later. I don't know if this is really feasible or sensible.

somehow tests are failing with below error:
`File "/home/travis/build/apache/incubator-airflow/airflow/www/views.py", line 1766, in redirect`
`   dttm = dateutil.parser.parse(execution_date)`
`NameError: global name 'dateutil' is not defined`

while many other methods using `dateutil` in `views.py`, also it passes in my local.
@msumit You need to rebase with apache:master, you're behind 52 commits.

I worked it out a little bit further. I have made Operators use the log of "airflow.task.operators" so it will bubble up to "airflow.task". This means that this:

```
[2017-12-01 11:24:56,874] {test.py:13} ERROR - Hello
[2017-12-01 11:24:56,874] {logging_mixin.py:94} INFO - [2017-12-01 11:24:56,874] {python_operator.py:91} INFO - Done. Returned value was: None
```

becomes:

```
[2017-12-01 12:13:29,086] {test.py:13} ERROR - Hello
[2017-12-01 12:13:29,086] {python_operator.py:91} INFO - Done. Returned value was: None
```

So no double log lines anymore.

@ashb PTAL (don't know yet if tests will pass)

Note: i might need to put the "RedirectStdHandler" back in, to accomodate for users that do

```
import logging

log = logging.getLogger()

```

In their DAGs.
Will test it out.

Can you remove the redirect? I don't think it is required. The button can be generated directly instead of being a redirect. Please also rename the Jira, because a redirect from a security point of view does not sound good.

Please rebase indeed, because dateutil should not be used anymore for parsing, but rather ```airflow.utils.timezone.parse```
Please make sure to run against latest master so that flake8 tests also run
cc @Fokko

@bolkedebruin will work on all the suggestions. But I am still not certain how to generate all links before rendering the page. Restating that, to achieve that we've to prepare all such links for all tasks of a DAG beforehand, which would be time-consuming.

I think applying this patch does something funny to the scheduler -- its sitting at 100% CPU and two of the processing children seem to never exit:

```
================================================================================
DAG File Processing Stats

File Path                                            PID  Runtime    Last Runtime    Last Run
-------------------------------------------------  -----  ---------  --------------  ----------
/usr/local/airflow/dags/brand_index.py
/usr/local/airflow/dags/semasio.py                    16  30.24s
/usr/local/airflow/dags/tapad_optout_pooler.py
/usr/local/airflow/dags/tapad_processor.py            15  30.27s
/usr/local/airflow/dags/example/csv_to_parquet.py
================================================================================
```

Under rc4 the runtime is usually ~1s, and Last Run column gets values
@ashb are you able to track where time is being spent?

@ashb Im not sure if your analysis is correct. If `raw` is specified the `try_number` is not increased. It is only increased when `_check_and_change_state_before_execution` is called, which only happens in a normal run scenario.

Entirely possible I got it wrong.

All I noticed was that some combo of `airflow run --local` to `airflow run --raw` ended up incremeneting the try_number from one to the other for the same job
Can you verify? The only place where try_number gets increased is at that check, which only happens with a normal run.

Yes, that's where it happens. I'm not sure what you mean by normal run though. (Or an abnormal run.) 

Using the celery executor you get a tree of processes like this:

```
celeryd
|- celery worker
    |-  airflow run $dag $task $date --local (try number starts at 0, is incremented to 1 before running next command)
      |-  airflow run $dag $task $date --job_id n --raw ( try_number 1 at start, resulting in writing to 2.log)
```
I haven't managed to track down the time yet. Will see if I can spare any time this afternoon
That is pretty weird, cause with "--raw" specified the increase should *not* happen, at least that is how I am reading the code.

Sorry, I wasn't clear. with `--raw` the increase to the row in the DB doesn't happen, but:

When created TI try_number=0
Log opened to ti.try_number+1 = `.../1.log`
`_check_and_change_state_before_execution` runs and updates ti.try_number in DB to 1 
`--raw` processs is invoked, it opens its log file to ti.try_number+1 = `.../2.log`.
Ah gotcha. All the more reason to start using the `start_date` for this.  Pff ok, there is no easy fix indeed

Now I just need to fix these tests. It's some shared state problem I think. If I (local) run _just_ the test file I changed it passes. Hrmmmm.

I'm totally stumped what is causing the failures. Running the tests locally, either directly on OSX, or in a docker image on linux the specific tests. But when run on Travis the log file is empty the reading code (`log += "*** Reading local log.\n" + "".join(f.readlines())`) Just returns `"** Reading local log.\n"`.

Gah.
Guys ( @bolkedebruin, @fenglu-g , @jgao54   and other committers) , I have created some more GCS operators. Can you review this one so that I can push the other operators?
@dhuang did you have a chance to test this? I am happy to iterate on the patch if you are still seeing issues.
Yup, I left it on overnight and didn't see any warnings about connection aborted. LGTM!
LGTM merging

> `Δ = absolute <relative> (impact)`, `ø = not affected`, `? = missing data`
> Powered by [Codecov](https://codecov.io/gh/apache/incubator-airflow/pull/2835?src=pr&el=footer). Last update [bdafb12...e5892c5](https://codecov.io/gh/apache/incubator-airflow/pull/2835?src=pr&el=lastupdated). Read the [comment docs](https://docs.codecov.io/docs/pull-request-comments).
I will fix the other issues separately and target them for 1.9.1. It is taking more time than expected

An option is to use an atexit registered function (https://docs.python.org/2/library/atexit.html). We should then increase the try_number at exit.

Another way is to do it in the scheduler, but I am not enthusiastic about that one. Imho try_number needs to go and be replaced by a log + start_date 

Third option is to update the try_number in cli.py before initalization of the log.

> **Legend** - [Click here to learn more](https://docs.codecov.io/docs/codecov-delta)
> `Δ = absolute <relative> (impact)`, `ø = not affected`, `? = missing data`
> Powered by [Codecov](https://codecov.io/gh/apache/incubator-airflow/pull/2836?src=pr&el=footer). Last update [9731ce6...9fc893d](https://codecov.io/gh/apache/incubator-airflow/pull/2836?src=pr&el=lastupdated). Read the [comment docs](https://docs.codecov.io/docs/pull-request-comments).
Will merge (tests work locally, core dump in this one that is unrelated)
Could you make a ticket in Jira? https://issues.apache.org/jira/projects/AIRFLOW This is for the release management and to keep track of why we made the changes.

I agree with Bolke, that there should be a single way of determining the run number. Can't we derive this from the database? Right now we're relying on `if ti.state == State.RUNNING:` which feels like a code smell to me, as in, we're relying on some external state.

@ashb I had the same, it turned out that my logging level was too low. If you are `> INFO`, then you won't see anything as the stdout is captured and passed into the INFO log handle.
Another option could be that I defer the initalization of the log until try-number has been increased. Probably not too hard given the other changes I am doing

atexit seems prone to not working all the time for me, but maybe it would be fine.

Moving to execution start date is probably a bigger change, but I could attempt that if we'd like. Though I'm not sure how the webserver log display/`.read()` would then be able to enumerate the logs. This question shows my lack of understanding of Airflow's models, but does each try get recorded as a TaskInstance in the DB? Or is each try just a Job? Do we store the start dates somewhere.

(Also when changing the log format some though should be given to how we make it possible to view old task logs when upgrading. To get them viewable from our 1.8.2 cluster after upgrading to 1.9.0rc4 I had a simple migration script that moved things in the s3 bucket by appending `/1.log` to the end of the current filename)

I'm going to continue poking at the tests for a bit longer. If I can't get it then I'll revert the test, and following Bolke's suggestion means I won't have to touch this bit of the code I'm currently testing so it won't need the same sort of tests.

Do you see a chance to get this into 1.9? Or has the release train already progressed too far? (Which I would also totally understand)
(Sorry for the commit noise for anyone following this thread.)
1.9.1 is the target. We are at rc for 1.9.0
That will do, thanks

@allisonwang thanks for joining in. What makes you think start_date is not unique? I don’t think we would need to have extra information when using start_date if we would name the log files with start_date instead of try_number. 

@ashb I think we could make this a bit cleaner, by making ‘try_number’ a property and using _try_number as a value holder. This ensures consistency also within taskinstance. What do you think?

@bolkedebruin As far as I remembered `utcnow` result depends on OS time which might not be in sync with multiple airflow workers and Python has up to millisecond accuracy. We could, in theory, ignore the differences. But still, it depends on values outside of the database and runs into the risk of having different task tries share the same start time and overwriting the logs.
cc @criccomini
Thanks @kaxil. Could you write a test for this? I.e. mocking the request.

+1 we are having this very same issue and is causing headaches in production.

To add my Use Case
- We trigger the Cluster creation
- It failed due to a Validation Error
- The Cluster start shutting down and the Steps are created
- Steps are marked as Cancelled
- Cluster shuts down.
lgtm~ looks like the error is transient and need a rebuild.
Please uppercase your Jira tag in the commit
Ah, sorry, forgot to put the JIRA in the PR description.  Commit subject uppercased.
As _log is set in __init__ it would change the signature and the tests would catch it richt away. So would it be really required?

Sorry you can’t do that for backfills this way. The backfill could actually be running and is independent of the scheduler doing its job. So while I agree there is an issue that needs to be fixed, this is not it. However for manually triggered jobs this is fine as they are guaranteed to be queued by the scheduler.

Makes sense, I'm not very familiar with the backfill internals so I figured there may be a good reason why that was special cased. 

I'll revert the backfill changes and keep the externally triggered changes.
The issue isn’t as bad for backfills btw, as they will be run from the command line. If they get killed there for some reason the user is in control.
sounds good to me

LGTM! Merged.

Please add a test and provide a commit message following the commit guidelines. Thanks!
Failed jobs are not running so why shoul they count towards max active runs?

If you have 20 DAGs, each with 20-30 tasks running every 30 minutes and it takes 4 hours to resolve the issue, you end up with 160 failed DAGs and 1000+ tasks, filling up your queue instead of 40 DAGs (if you have max dag run set to 2). Because, when a task fails in DAG_1, DAG_2 comes in the queue and aborts the same task in that DAG, and so on. Much easier to manage when you need to catch up with data and restart tasks.

Possible alternative option would be to add the failed_count to airflow.cfg
@bolkedebruin Further fixup commit pushed, and commented. PTAL.
